title_sort: john b. pratt to walt whitman, 6 january 1865
title: John B. Pratt to Walt Whitman, 6 January 1865
text: Williamson Wayne, Co. N.Y.Aug 6thWalt dear son Alfred we received a letter last night you and was pained to hear that wore[were] sick in the in a faren[foreign] and among strangers, oh if and your Mother could be there to take care of you it would be some consolation, but you said you were better did not say what your complaint was we hope for the best it may be when you get this you will be well but if not write in hast[haste] or get some to write the particulars. we are all well at the time the weather is and very warm. we have planting and sowing I sowed on the north of the barn and that too nowhere had year the road all sowed to and we plant from tot he ditch about 3 acres down north ploued[plowed] I have set one hundred apple trees there and 72 grape vines. and the plowing they make good . I don't think of much to the best you can and come home the first opportunity rite[write] soon without fail and rite[write] if you want me you anything and by, B.S.John B. PrattWilliamsonWayne Co. N Y John B. Pratt to Walt Whitman, 6 January 1865
